awd_titl_txt: CPS: Medium: Collaborative Research: Constantly on the Lookout: Low-cost Sensor Enabled Explosive Detection to Protect High Density Environments
awd_abstract_narration:
This project aims to empower ordinary citizens to take charge in collecting real time environmental data that can be used to serve a common interest. The target application of the project is a cyber-physical system for detecting small amounts of explosive vapor in the air so as to protect large-area public gatherings. In this system, extremely low-cost explosive sensors, handed out free of charge, will be connected to the smart phones of the willing participants, effectively turning each one of them into a look-out sensor node. Although the primary application of the proposed cyber-physical system is explosive detection, problems with similar technical challenges include air pollution monitoring systems, pandemic prevention, fire and/or gas leak monitoring. Successful completion of this project will generate a plethora of new applications that target problems with the aim of reaching a common goal by leveraging computation, power, and communications capacities donated by willing participants. Understanding that interest in STEM (science, technology, engineering, math)-related careers begins in elementary school, the project will use a sensor-based system that aims at locating a heat source, as part of K-12 outreach activities that explore crowd-sourced data collection, processing, and scheduling. The researchers work regularly with undergraduate and high school students through Fulton Undergraduate Research Initiative (FURI), Barrett Summer Scholars (BSS), National Science Foundation-sponsored National Nanotechnology Infrastructure Network Research Experience for Undergraduates (NNIN REU), and Arizona State University's Summer Research Experience for High School Students program. 

Designing a system based on extremely low-cost sensors for crowd-sourced monitoring has several unique technical and scientific challenges that the project tackles. First, cost/power requirements and the need to detect tiny amounts of explosive vapor are at odds with each other. Second, the system will be designed to tolerate inevitable sensor inaccuracies and false positives/negatives in a stable manner. Third, since the entire system hinges on willing participation from the public, sensor operation will be made transparent to the user, and not create a negative user experience. Finally, privacy concerns of the users will be addressed by keeping them anonymous, and the security threats generated by this anonymity will be addressed.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project is to create a cyber physical system for the detection of chemical threats, specifically explosive devices, in a crowded event such as a concert or football game. The concept is based on the principle of crowd-sourcing, where participants donate existing resources in their possession (i.e. cellular phones with internet connectivity) whenever they are idle to achieve a common security goal.  The participants are provided with extremely low-cost chemical sensors that can be paired with mobile devices. Large area coverage is achieved by the natural movement of the participants, as well as the large number of distributed sensors. The large number of mobile sensor units overcomes two challenges related to low-cost chemical sensors, namely low sensitivity and large variation in the response.

In order to develop such a system, various technical challenges need to be overcome. At the system-level, tracking sensor readings and location, detection, and routing of system-level resources (i.e. security personnel) have to be managed. At host-device level, it is important to develop algorithms to avoid a negative user experience. Transparent operation of the host-level is of utmost importance. The donated resources need to be scaled with respect to the user-run applications on the device and should not generate a burden on the host device. Furthermore, sensor readings and location information are compiled with the sensor identification number, which is not tied in any way to the user. This guarantees privacy of individuals while providing the ability to track sensor readings for each sensor device.

The research team has developed sever-level and host-level algorithms with the above mentioned characteristics, as well as prototype sensor devices that include both in-house developed semiconductor wafers and commercially available wafers coated with molecules that have a high affinity to ammonia, which is one of the key ingredients in explosive devices.

Low-cost sensors suffer from degrading sensitivity, drift, as well as high sensor-to-sensor variability. To avoid a large number of false positives, the research team has developed both image processing based and machine learning based algorithms that detect, compensate, and overcome sensor inaccuracies. Algorithms for detecting outlier sensors and deciding which sensors should be reset using the host hardware were developed and demonstrated using data collected by the research team. Sensor-to-sensor variations were overcome by algorithms were developed to keep track of the drifting baseline readings from each sensor and use relative readings to make detection decisions. Server-level algorithms for detection were developed to prevent a large number false positives from overwhelming the security personnel.

Locating the source of a positive reading is one of the important challenges in such a system as participants move around and sensor may have a large variation between their readings. Two techniques were developed for source location. One technique is based on the principles of triangulation, similar to determining the location of a cellular phone based on signal strength to multiple base stations. This technique requires that sensors are calibrated with respect to a common baseline, which can be achieved during post-production test. Triangulation technique can locate the source within centimeters with a relative low number of positive readings (3-5). However, the calibration requirement raises the cost of post-production testing for each individual sensor. In addition, a deep-learning based localization algorithm was developed where large amounts of data are used to train a deep neural network off-line, and this network is used during the event to localize the source if a positive reading is detected by any sensor. The deep-learning based algorithm does not need each sensor to be calibrated with respect to baseline but it requires large data sets to train the network.

This interdisciplinary project, which combined the principles from chemistry, semiconductor manufacturing, electronic circuit design, firmware development, digital signal processing, and artificial intelligence, has helped train 8 doctoral students, 4 master students, and 22 undergraduate students across 4 institutions. Graduate students were heavily involved in the research project, collaborating across multiple institutions, co-authoring research papers, and presenting their work to large audiences during conferences. 10 of the 12 graduate students have obtained their degrees and have been employed by various domestic semiconductor and software companies. To recruit undergraduate students, course modules and senior design projects were developed. Overall, 5 senior design groups have been recruited at collaborating institutions to work on various research and development aspects of this project. 11 of the 34 students that were involved in the project were from under-represented groups. 8 undergraduate students were recruited to work on the project through the Research Experiences for Undergraduates (REU) program. 4 REU students also attended the annual Cyber-Physical Systems Principle Investigator meeting, where they presented the project poster.
